item.label: Cerebral gyri
item.name: Cerebral gyri
item.description: The surface of the cerebral hemispheres is folded or convoluted into cerebral gyri (the elevations) and cerebral sulci (the valleys).

item.label: Cingulate gyrus
item.name: Cingulate gyri
item.description: The cingulate gyrus is the region of the cerebral cortex that arcs above the corpus callosum on the medial aspect of the hemisphere. Along with the parahippocampal gyrus to which it is connected by the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus, posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum, it is considered to be the "Limbic lobe" of the brain.

item.label: Insula
item.name: Insula
item.description: The insula is an area of cerebral cortex (AKA insular cortex or Island of Reil) that is concealed by the opercula of the frontal, parietal and temporal gyri. It was originally the lateral surface of the telencephalon but was overgrown during development by the other cerebral lobes. It generally consists of three short gyri located anteriorly and two long gyri located posteriorly.

item.label: Parahippocampal gyrus
item.name: Parahippocampal gyri
item.description: The parahippocampal gyrus is the most medial gyrus on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe. The hippocampus is cortex that is rolled up inside the parahippocampal gyrus. The rostral portion of this gyrus is the entorhinal cortex.

item.label: Uncus
item.name: Uncus
item.description: The uncus is a bulge on the anterior aspect of the parahippocampal gyrus caused by the underlying amygdala. it can herniate through the tentorial notch in the event of increased intracranial pressure due to a supratentorial space-occupying lesion.

item.label: Cerebral sulci & fissures
item.name: Cerebral sulci_fissures
item.description: A cerebral fissure is AKA a cerebral sulcus (sing.); sulci (pl.).  Fissures are the depressions or grooves between the gyri or convolutions of the cerebral cortex.  Fissure generally refers to a sulcus that is particularly deep.  The terms are used interchangeably in some cases.

item.label: Longitudinal fissure
item.name: Longitudinal fissure
item.description: The longitudinal cerebral fissure is AKA the median longitudinal fissure. it is a deep midline fissure located between the two cerebral hemispheres.  The cerebral falx (a dural reflection) extends into this fissure.

item.label: Lateral sulcus
item.name: Lateral sulci
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Transverse fissure
item.name: Transverse fissure
item.description: The transverse fissure is a portion of the subarachnoid space that extends from the area containing the tentorium cerebelli forward to include the superior cistern and then extending over the roof of the third ventricle. The paired internal cerebral veins travel in this space as they join the great vein of Galen and then the straight sinus.

item.label: Commissure,Corpus callosum,Body
item.name: Commissure Corpus callosum, body
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Hippocampal formation
item.name: Hippocampal formation
item.description: The hippocampus is AKA the hippocampal formation. It is an area of cerebral cortex rolled up inside the medial aspect of the temporal lobe. It is part of the limbic system and functions in the consolidation of new memories of facts and events. It has three subdivisions: the hippocampus proper (Ammon's horn), the dentate gyrus, and the subiculum. The fornix carries the primary output from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal area and hypothalamus.

item.label: Fornix, crus & body
item.name: Fornix, crus_body
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus.  Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Internal capsule, Posterior limb
item.name: Internal capsule Posterior limb
item.description: The posterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lentiform nucleus laterally and the thalamus medially. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA), ventral lateral (VL), ventral posterior nuclei (VPL/VPM) of thalamus with the motor, somatosensory and other areas of parietal cerebral cortex as well as corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers. A portion of the posterior limb passes beneath the lentiform nucleus (sublenticular); it includes the auditory radiation from the medial geniculate nucleus of thalamus to the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex and a portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to the occipital cerebral cortex. A portion of the posterior limb passes posterior to the lentiform nucleus (retrolenticular); it includes a major portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to occipital cerebral cortex plus connections between the thalamus (pulvinar and lateral posterior nuclei) and the parietal-occipital-temporal association cortex.

item.label: External capsule
item.name: External capsule
item.description: The external capsule is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the lentiform nucleus and medial to the claustrum. It includes fibers connecting the cerebral cortex with the striatum (putamen and caudate).

item.label: Claustrum
item.name: Claustrum
item.description: The claustrum is a thin, layered nucleus located between the external and extreme capsules (and thus between the lentiform nucleus and the insula). Function is unknown.

item.label: Extreme capsule
item.name: Extreme capsule
item.description: The extreme capsule is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the claustrum and medial to the cortex of the insula. It contains cortical association nerve fibers.

item.label: Amygdala
item.name: Amygdala
item.description: The amygdala consists of a group of nuclei located near the anterior and medial aspect of the temporal lobe, immediately beneath the uncus. Location is immediately anterior to the anterior tip of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. Output from the amygdala via the stria terminalis contributes to the major limbic system circuits. Essential role in emotions and their behavioral expression.

item.label: Corpus striatum
item.name: Corpus striatum
item.description: The corpus striatum includes the caudate nuclei, putamen and globus pallidus.  These nuclei are often referred to as the basal ganglia.   Note that the term "striatum" includes only the caudate nuclei plus the putamen.

item.label: Caudate nucleus, Body
item.name: Caudate nuclei, body
item.description: The body of the caudate nucleus is the slender mid-portion that is continuous with the head of the caudate nucleus rostrally and with the tail of the caudate nucleus, caudally.

item.label: Lentiform nucleus
item.name: Lentiform nuclei
item.description: The lentiform nuclei are AKA the lenticular nuclei. These nuclei include the putamen and globus pallidus. Located lateral to the internal capsule and medial to the external capsule, claustrum, extreme capsule and insula, the lenticular nucleus fills the "V" formed by the lateral surface of the internal capsule.

item.label: Putamen
item.name: Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Globus pallidus
item.name: Globus pallidus
item.description: The globus pallidus is a wedge-shaped nucleus located medial to the putamen and fitting into the "V" on the lateral aspect of the internal capsule. With the putamen, it is known as the lentiform or lenticular nucleus. It is the origin of most efferents from the basal ganglia. Includes an internal and an external segment.

item.label: External medullary lamina
item.name: External medullary lamina
item.description: The external medullary lamina of the globus pallidus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the external segment of the globus pallidus and medial to the putamen.  Do not confuse with the external medullary lamina of the thalamus.

item.label: External segment
item.name: External segment
item.description: The lateral component of the globus pallidus is known as the external segment.  It receives afferents from the striatum and subthalamic nucleus and sends efferents to the subthalamic nucleus via the subthalamic fasciculus.

item.label: Internal medullary lamina
item.name: Internal medullary lamina
item.description: The internal medullary lamina of the globus pallidus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the internal segment of the globus pallidus and medial to the external segment of the globus pallidus.  Do not confuse with the internal medullary lamina of the thalamus.

item.label: Internal segment
item.name: Internal segment
item.description: The medial component of the globus pallidus is known as the internal segment. It receives afferents from the striatum and subthalamic nucleus and sends efferents to the thalamus via the ansa lenticularis and lenticular fasciculus.

item.label: Thalamic fasciculus
item.name: Thalamic fasciculus
item.description: The thalamic fasciculus (AKA H1 Field of Forel) is a bundle of nerve fibers located beneath the ventral anterior and ventral lateral thalamic nuclei. It includes output from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle and from the basal ganglia via the ansa lenticularis and lenticular fasciculus (AKA H2 Field of Forel).

item.label: Lenticular fasciculus
item.name: Lenticular fasciculus
item.description: The lenticular fasciculus is AKA the H2 Field of Forel.  It is a bundle of nerve fibers that extends from the internal segment of the globus pallidus to the thalamus. Running medially through the internal capsule as a series of fiber bundles, it joins the ansa lenticularis before they both enter the thalamus.

item.label: Stria & Vena terminales
item.name: Stria_vena terminales
item.description: The stria terminalis and vena terminalis run together through the lateral ventricle in the groove between the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.  The stria terminalis is a small fiber bundle that is part of the limbic system.  It originates in the amygdala and terminates in the septal area and hypothalamus. The vena terminalis is AKA the terminal vein and is part of the system of deep cerebral veins that drain the interior of the cerebrum.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Lateral dorsal nucleus
item.name: Lateral dorsal nuclei
item.description: The lateral dorsal nucleus of the thalamus sends efferents to the posterior aspect of the cingulate gyrus.

item.label: Medial dorsal nucleus
item.name: Medial dorsal nuclei
item.description: The dorsomedial nucleus of the thalamus (DM) is AKA the medial dorsal nucleus.  It is located medial to the internal medullary lamina of the thalamus.  It has important connections with the prefrontal association cortex and the limbic system.

item.label: Reticular nucleus
item.name: Reticular nuclei
item.description: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus is a thin shell of neurons surrounding the ventral and lateral aspect of the thalamus. It is sandwiched between the internal capsule and the external medullary lamina of the thalamus. It has no projections to cerebral cortex. It receives afferents from the thalamus and cerebral cortex and sends GABAergic efferents back to the thalamus.

item.label: Ventral lateral nucleus
item.name: Ventral lateral nuclei
item.description: The ventral lateral thalamic nucleus (VL) is the thalamic relay for motor control. It receives input form the basal ganglia, cerebellum and cerebral cortex and projects to the motor and premotor cortex via the internal capsule.

item.label: External medullary lamina
item.name: Ext. medullary lamina
item.description: The external medullary lamina of the thalamus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the thalamus and medial to the reticular nucleus of the thalamus and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Note: Do not confuse with the external medullary lamina that is located between the globus pallidus and putamen.

item.label: Stria medullaris of thalamus
item.name: Stria medullaris
item.description: The stria medullaris of the thalamus is a thin fiber bundle that appears as a horizontal ridge on the dorsal and medial aspect of the thalamus.  It originates in the septal nuclei and terminates in the habenular nuclei. The roof of the third ventricle stretches between the stria medullaris of the thalamus on the two sides.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Mammillary body
item.name: Mammillary bodies
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Mamillothalamic tract
item.name: Mamillothalamic tracts
item.description: The mammillothalamic tract is a bundle of fibers projecting from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. It is part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Subthalamus
item.name: Subthalamus
item.description: The subthalamus is one of the four divisions of the diencephalon.  It is located ventral to the thalamus, lateral to the hypothalamus and medial to the internal capsule and cerebral peduncle.  It contains the subthalamic nucleus and the zona incerta.  It is traversed by the somatosensory pathways on their way to the thalamus as well as by pathways connecting the cerebellum and basal ganglia.  It is continuous caudally with rostral portions of the red nucleus and substantia nigra.

item.label: Subthalamic nucleus
item.name: Subthalamic nuclei
item.description: The subthalamic nucleus is a bi-convex lens-shaped nucleus located just medial and superior to the junction of the internal capsule and crus cerebri. The subthalamic nucleus is part of an indirect route through the basal ganglia whereby it receives input from the external segment of the globus pallidus and returns it output to the internal segment of the globus pallidus. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus produces hemiballismus on the contralateral side of the body.

item.label: Zona incerta
item.name: Zona incerta
item.description: The zona incerta is a thin sheet of gray matter located between the subthalamic nuclueus and the thalamus, surrounded by the nerve fibers leaving the globus pallidus. It contains GABA-ergic neurons that project widely to the cerebral cortex.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic tract
item.name: Visual pathway Optic tracts
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerebral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Arteries, Middle cerebral
item.name: Arteries, middle cerebral
item.description: The middle cerebral artery is the most posterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it travels through the lateral sulcus to supply the insula, the lateral aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes and the anterior tip of the temporal lobe. Since the middle cerebral artery supplies the pre- and post-central gyri which are responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso.

item.label: Ventricular system
item.name: Ventricular system
item.description: The ventricular system is a series of interconnected cerebrospinal-filled chambers within the cerebral hemispheres. Cerebrospinal fluid is formed in the choroid plexus located in the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricles
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body
item.description: The body of the lateral ventricle is located between the anterior horn, rostrally, and the atrium or trigone, caudally.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Inferior horn
item.name: Inferior horn
item.description: The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is AKA the temporal horn. This region of the lateral ventricle extends into the temporal lobe.

item.label: Third ventricle
item.name: Third ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.
